title: BTS's 'Love Yourself: Tear' is a Triumph
summary: “Love Yourself: Tear” is a reminder to K-pop fans that vocals can be just as important as dance moves. BTS’s main vocalist, Kim Nam-joon, or RM, has always been the strong point of the group but on “Tear’, he shines even brighter. “Fake Love” and ‘Tear are the type of tracks that listeners might not pick up on their first few listens but will appreciate once they've fully digested the EP.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In a world where every band is a boy band, BTS stands out. The Korean sextet has made a name for itself as not just another boy band but one that plays its own instruments and has choreographed dance routines that are so intricate they sometimes require special stage lighting.
Armed with these weapons, BTS has twice cracked the top 10 on the Billboard 200 album chart with its Love Yourself series. And the latest installment of this series \u2014 which doubles as its sixth EP \u2014 is no exception.
Furthermore, it\u2019s the strongest of the bunch.
It\u2019s impossible to talk about BTS without mentioning their massive following beyond Korea: Vivid, obsessive ARMYs (as they call them) who follow their every move and buy everything associated with them. This is why many people assume they are only famous because of social media and pandering ads (which is true). However, anyone who listens to their music will tell you that they deserve all this success. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D proves it once again.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"The Importance of \u2018Tear\u2019"),mdx("p",null,"There are two songs on \u201CTear\u201D that are called \u201CFake Love\u201D and \u201CTear.\u201D The connection between these two songs is not accidental: The tear is a sign of strength rather than weakness. As BTS lead vocalist Kim Nam-joon, known as RM, said in an interview with Billboard, \u201CThe difference between \u2018Fake Love\u2019 and \u2018Tear\u2019 is that in \u2018Fake Love\u2019, there was a lot of blame, there was a lot of \u2018you did this wrong\u2019, and \u2018you did this wrong\u2019. Whereas \u2018Tear\u2019 is really accepting the fact that it\u2019s all your fault, and you have to go through it.\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"Prologue: Remember Yourself"),mdx("p",null,`The first track on the EP \u2014 \u201CEuphoria\u201D \u2014 is a prelude to the rest of the album. It\u2019s a brief, one-minute and 33-second-long jumble of sounds that act as a reminder of who BTS are and what first connected them to their fans.
Dance breakers may enjoy this track the most because it\u2019s a full-on mix of mechanically programmed sounds and rhythmic beats that are somewhat reminiscent of the \u201890s.
It\u2019s like a trip down memory lane for fans who remember the band\u2019s roots. It\u2019s like BTS is saying \u201CRemember who we are? This is who we are.\u201D`),mdx("h2",null,"Tear and the Importance of Vocals in K-pop"),mdx("p",null,`The K-pop industry is primarily known for its dance routines and catchy hooks. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D is a reminder to K-pop fans that vocals can be just as important as dance moves.
RM\u2019s vocals on \u201CFake Love\u201D are some of his strongest to date. He sings in both Korean and English throughout the track.
BTS\u2019s main vocalist, Kim Nam-joon, or RM, has always been the strong point of the group but on \u201CTear\u201D, he shines even brighter.
Namjoon sings with a certain amount of controlled emotion in both Korean and English on \u201CTear\u201D.`),mdx("h2",null,"The Darker Side of Love"),mdx("p",null,"The next two tracks \u2014 \u201CSuga\u201D and \u201CSeesaw\u201D \u2014 illustrate the darker side of love. They\u2019re the type of tracks that listeners might not pick up on their first few listens but will appreciate once they\u2019ve fully digested the EP. These tracks are less obvious than \u201CFake Love\u201D and \u201CTear\u201D. They aren\u2019t supposed to be obvious; they\u2019re supposed to be subtle and immersive."),mdx("p",null,`These two tracks are BTS\u2019s way of saying that love isn\u2019t all hearts and flowers. There are thorns and thistles that come from it, too.
These tracks prove that BTS isn\u2019t here for the sweet, saccharine love everyone talks about. They\u2019re here for the more realistic and often more complicated side of love.`),mdx("h2",null,"BTS\u2019s Vocals Are On Point in \u2018Tear\u2019"),mdx("p",null,`If there was ever a time to be a BTS fan and a K-pop listener, it\u2019s now. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D is a reminder that BTS is an actual band with real instruments and not just a group of people who dance and sing in unison.
The drums, guitars, and pianos in these tracks are almost as important as the vocals. They aren\u2019t just pretty pieces of music; they have a purpose.
And BTS\u2019s use of instruments and vocals all come together to create a masterpiece.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"What makes BTS\u2019s \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D so special is that it proves the band isn\u2019t here to pander to their fans. They\u2019re not going to spit out songs about falling in love, being in love, and being heartbroken. They\u2019re here to make music that reflects their lives and how they feel about the world around them."),mdx("p",null,"BTS writes songs about the struggles that younger people face today. They write about growing pains, the pressures of university life, the difficulty of being in a relationship, and the difficulty of being alone. They write about the darker side of love \u2014 the side that isn\u2019t all hearts and flowers. END"),mdx("p",null,"In a world where every band is a boy band, BTS stands out. The Korean sextet has made a name for itself as not just another boy band but one that plays its own instruments and has choreographed dance routines that are so intricate they sometimes require special stage lighting."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Babadook" Is a Haunting and Original Horror Film

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...a}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...a,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`While there has been some great music released this year, the first half of 2018 has not been an exceptional one for new releases. However, that doesn\u2019t mean there hasn\u2019t been some brilliant albums released so far this year. While last year had some incredible albums (like Kendrick Lamar\u2019s \u201CDamn,\u201D Lorde\u2019s \u201CMelodrama,\u201D and Noel Gallagher\u2019s High Flying Birds' "Who Built the Moon?"), this year hasn\u2019t quite matched up to those standards. However, we are only halfway through the year and as such, we have also seen some fantastic new albums released in the last few months that are worth mentioning. There may not be many great new albums out at the moment \u2013 but these five are definitely among the best.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

"Imitation of Life" Is a Thought-Provoking Drama about Race and Identity
"The Grapes of Wrath" Is a Classic of American Literature
All Time Low's 'Last Young Renegade' Is a Must-Listen
"Bridge of Spies" Is a Masterful Cold War Thriller

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`With the specter of mutually assured destruction looming over every global crisis and proxy conflict, the Cold War is perhaps one of the most fraught periods in history. There are no heroes in this period\u2014just two paranoid superpowers scrambling to maintain the upper hand, irrespective of cost. The inherent darkness and moral ambiguity of that period makes for fantastic fodder for any storyteller looking to immerse their audience in a stark world where there are no easy answers.
The 1980s was a peak moment in that tension\u2014from Reagan\u2019s \u201Cevil empire\u201D speech and constant saber-rattling, to the U.S.-backed Contra War against Communist rebels in Nicaragua and an escalation of tensions between NATO and the USSR all around the globe. In brief: It was not a good time to be alive if you believed in world peace. Thankfully, Hollywood had spies as intrepid as Tom Hanks ready to leap into action against those dastardly Soviet Commies whenever they needed someone captured or rescued from behind enemy lines.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Big Short" Is a Searing Indictment of the Financial Industry

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The film version of The Big Short hits theaters this Friday, and it\u2019s not subtle. Its tagline is \u201CThere\u2019s a sucker born every minute. But they don\u2019t grow up thinking they can be con men. They get taught to be one.\u201D And its trailer goes on to say, \u201CThe housing bubble was about to burst\u2026 And a group of misfits saw it coming. Now these unlikely heroes must band together and bring down the greedy villains who crashed the world economy\u2026 Before anyone else gets hurt.\u201D
Unfortunately, that last part is not hyperbole. The actions of unscrupulous financial engineers \u2014 colloquially known as \u201Cbankers\u201D \u2014 led directly to the Great Recession in 2008, which cost millions their jobs and homes, while triggering widespread deflation and anemic growth throughout much of the developed world for years thereafter.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
